content.title: Security Related Expenditure (Relief and Rehabilitation)
content.details: The scheme 'Security Related Expenditure (Relief and Rehabilitation)' also known as 'SRE (R&R) Scheme' was introduced in 1989-90 by the Jammu and Kashmir Division, Ministry of Home Affairs to support the relief and rehabilitation of the Kashmiri migrants who have been uprooted from the Valley during the militancy period. It provides for 100% reimbursement. 60% of the amount is reimbursed upfront on receipt of claims and the remaining 40% is released after receipt of the audit report. It broadly covers relief to Kashmiri and Jammu migrants, expenditure incurred on PM's package for return and rehabilitation of Kashmiri migrants, relief to NoKs of civilians/security personnel killed in militant-related attacks, rehabilitation of surrendered militants etc. 'SRE (R&R) Scheme' is a component of the Umbrella scheme, 'Modernization of Police Forces (MPF)'. SRE (R&R) is funded entirely by the Central Government.
benefits: Cash relief to Kashmiri and Jammu migrants settled in J&K: ₹3,250 per person per month, with a maximum of ₹13,000 per family per month.
Cash relief to Kashmiri migrants settled in Delhi/NCR: ₹3,250 per person per month, with a maximum of ₹13,000 per family per month.
Cash relief to migrants in the hilly areas of the Jammu division, equivalent to Kashmiri migrants: ₹2,500 per person per month, with a maximum of ₹10,000 per family per month.

Relief for ration/fodder to migrants in hilly areas of Jammu division, including 9 kg of Atta, 2 kg of Rice per person per month, and 10 litres of kerosene oil per family per month, along with ₹300 per cattle per month for fodder.
Basic dry ration for needy migrants, including 9 kgs of rice, 2 kgs of Atta per person, and 1 kg of sugar per family per month, with additional ex-gratia relief for property loss, up to ₹10,00,000.
eligibility: The beneficiary should be Kashmir or Jammu Migrant.
content.application_process: Offline. Claims for the reimbursement of Security Related Expenditures should be submitted using the prescribed proforma, duly certified by an officer, not below the rank of Additional Secretary to the concerned State Government.
documents_required: Details of the Aadhaar-linked Bank Account

faqs.question: Can citizens directly access funding under the SRE scheme for any projects or activities?
faqs.answer: The SRE scheme primarily involves reimbursements to the Government of Jammu and Kashmir, and individual citizens do not directly access funding.

faqs.question: Could you provide the full names of the mentioned initials in the scheme, such as IFD-MHA and CCS?
faqs.answer: Certainly. IFD-MHA stands for 'Internal Finance Division, Ministry of Home Affairs,' and CCS stands for 'Cabinet Committee on Security.'

faqs.question: Are there specific opening and closing dates for citizens to apply for benefits under SRE?
faqs.answer: The scheme does not mention specific opening and closing dates for individual citizens, as it primarily deals with government reimbursements.

faqs.question: What is the mode of application for individuals or organizations interested in participating in SRE schemes?
faqs.answer: The SRE schemes are primarily administered between the Central Government and the State Government, and individual citizens are not direct participants.

faqs.question: How does the declaration process work for citizens applying for benefits under SRE?
faqs.answer: The scheme primarily deals with government claims and reimbursement; therefore, there is no declaration process for individual citizens.

faqs.question: How does the Ministry of Home Affairs review the accounts and expenditure under the SRE(R&R) scheme?
faqs.answer: The Ministry of Home Affairs may periodically send teams to the State to conduct sample checks of the SRE(R&R) accounts maintained by the State Government.

faqs.question: What is the prescribed Proforma for submitting claims for reimbursement of Security Related Expenditure?
faqs.answer: Claims should be submitted using the prescribed Proforma mentioned in Annex C of the scheme.

faqs.question: How is the funding pattern regulated for schemes and projects under SRE?
faqs.answer: Schemes and projects receive 100% funding from the Central Government.

faqs.question: Under what circumstances can advance releases be considered for SRE(J&K): R&R?
faqs.answer: In special circumstances and with the approval of the SRE Standing Committee, advance releases may be considered.

faqs.question: Can you explain the categories of people served by the SRE(J&K): Relief and Rehabilitation (R&R) scheme?
faqs.answer: The scheme caters to categories including Kashmiri and Jammu Migrants, victims of violence, border population, and those affected by cross-border firing and terrorism.

faqs.question: What is the purpose of the SRE(J&K): Relief and Rehabilitation (R&R) scheme, and when was it introduced?
faqs.answer: The SRE(J&K): Relief and Rehabilitation (R&R) scheme was introduced in 1989-90 to reimburse expenses incurred by the Government of J&K for various Relief and Rehabilitation activities.

faqs.question: Who oversees matters related to the reimbursement of SRE to the State of Jammu and Kashmir?
faqs.answer: The SRE Standing Committee, chaired by the Special Secretary (J&K), oversees matters related to reimbursement of SRE to the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

faqs.question: When did the SRE scheme become effective, and what is the funding arrangement?
faqs.answer: The SRE scheme became effective from the financial year 2000-01, with a 100% fund reimbursement.
